paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, as inferred from JWST MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy and spectral structure near the 15 um CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: JWST MIRI orbital phase-curve spectroscopy
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One orbital phase curve with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Low-resolution JWST MIRI spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band for TRAPPIST-1 b.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: No-atmosphere (bare-rock) null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One modeled scenario compared against the observed phase curve and spectrum
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-free, bare-rock model with minimal heat redistribution used as a null scenario in retrieval comparisons against phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model family emphasizing greenhouse-gas absorption and the 15 um CO2 band, used to interpret spectral structure and joint constraints from phase curve plus spectrum.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model family with oxidized composition and weaker CO2 signature constraints, evaluated as an alternative that is not fully ruled out by the current dataset.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
